text: This law expands the definition of business enterprise in the entertainment industry to include affiliates that are registered for and authorized to use the E-Verify system.

This law adds language to allow licensure of those who graduated from a nursing education program outside the U.S. that is determined by the board to be equivalent to and not less stringent than an approved nursing education program.

America's Founding Philosophy and Principles Act provides for the ability of each local board of education to require all students, as a condition of graduation, during their ninth through twelfth grade years to complete and pass a separate semester course covering the founding philosophy and principles of the U.S.

This law amends appropriations for the Fiscal Year beginning July 1, 2011 to include $8,749,006 of federal funds and grants to provide employment, health screening, medical, cash and social service assistance to refugees.

The purpose of this appropriation is to reimburse members of the Immigration Enforcement Review Board for expenses incurred in connection with the investigation and review of complaints alleging failure of public agencies or employees to properly adhere to federal and state laws related to the federal work authorization program E-Verify.

This budget allocates $9,303,613 for Refugee Assistance, to provide employment, health screening, medical, cash, and social services assistance to refugees for fiscal year 2015. Additionally, $20,000 is appropriated to the Immigration Enforcement Review Board in fiscal year 2015 to reimburse members for expenses incurred in connection with the investigation and review of complaints alleging failure of public agencies or employees to properly adhere to federal and state laws related to the federal work authorization program E-Verify.
This appropriations law includes funds for the Immigration Enforcement Review Board and funds to provide refugee assistance.

This budget allocates $9,303,613 to Refugee Assistance to provide employment, health screening, medical, cash, and social services assistance to refugees for fiscal year 2016. Additionally, $20,000 is appropriated to the Immigration Enforcement Review Board in fiscal year 2016 to reimburse members for expenses incurred in connection with the investigation and review of complaints alleging failure of public agencies or employees to properly adhere to federal and state laws related to the federal work authorization program E-Verify.

This law assigns the Georgia Charter Schools Commission the duty to review the citizenship and immigration status of each individual that works at a state charter school and to aggregate the information by school on an annual basis.

This law states that all motor carriers and applicants for limousine chauffeur shall be a U.S. citizen, or be able to present federal documentation verified by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security as valid evidence of lawful presence in the United States.
This law related to secondary metals recyclers removes a work authorization issued by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services in the definition of a personal identification card.
This law addressing wages includes a definition of employers that includes their registration and authorization to use E-Verify.
This resolution honors Councilwoman Dianne Leonetti for her services to Georgia, who served the refugee community through her church.

This resolution commends the members of the St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee, Chairman Jerry Hogan, Jr., and the Grand Marshal of the 2016 St. Patrick's Day Parade on the upcoming occasion of the 2016 St. Patrick's Day Parade in Savannah, Georgia. The St. Patrick's Day Parade began in 1824 in order to aid early Irish immigrants in Georgia.

This resolution recognizes February 9 as Community Health Centers Day. Community health centers provide high quality primary and preventive health care to 400,000 people in the State of Georgia, including Medicaid recipients, the uninsured, the working poor and immigrants.

This resolution recognizes February 10, 2016, as New Americans Day at the capitol. This day marks the second annual United States Citizenship and Immigration Services Naturalization Ceremony in the State Capitol Rotunda welcoming new citizens to Georgia's ranks.

This resolution recognizes Mr. Derrick Kayongo and congratulating him upon his appoint as the new CEO of the Center for Civil and Human Rights. Mr. Kayongo fled a civil war in Uganda and settled as a refugee in Kenya to later immigrate to the United States.
This resolution commends Nicole Chai for her significant contributions to Georgia. Nicole Chai comes from an immigrant family, and is the first generation born in the United States.

This resolution commends the Islamic Circle of North America (ICNA) Relief as being the nation's only Muslim disaster relief center that has done great work. In Georgia, the ICNA provides ESL classes for female immigrants.

This resolution commends Angie's House, Inc., created out of a need to bring attention to children and youth who are exposed to violence in the home, focuses on breaking the cycle of abuse and helping the community understand that intimate partner violence affects children and youth regardless of race, ethnicity, class, sexual and gender identity, religious affiliation, age, or immigration status.

This resolution recognizes March 23, 2016, as Pakistani American Day at the state capitol. Recognizes that Pakistani immigrants have help[ed to turn emergent areas within the State of Georgia into thriving and respectable communities, while raising their children to be productive Pakistani Americans.

This resolution commends the members of the St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee, Chairman Jerry Hogan, Jr., and the Grand Marshal of the 2016 St. Patrick's Day Parade on the upcoming occasion of the 2016 St. Patrick's Day Parade in Savannah, Georgia. The St. Patrick's Day Parade began in 1824 in order to aid early Irish immigrants in Georgia.

This resolution recognizes and honors the members of the St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee 2012 and the upcoming St. Patrick's day parade, the 188th celebration which was begun in 1824 by the Hibernian Society of Savannah formed to aid the early Irish immigrants to Georgia.
This resolution recognizes March 11, 2016 as Caribbean American Legislative Day, and the contributions that Caribbean American immigrants have made to Georgia.

This resolution recognizes February 3, 2015, as Catholic Day at the state capitol. The Archdiocese of Atlanta and the Diocese of Savannah, through their institutions and their people, have continued to reach out in service to all people in Georgia, including newcomers and long established families from all parts of the world, including refugees, immigrants, and those seeking asylum from religious and political oppression.

Honors Roberto Moraes born in Sao Paulo, Brazil who worked 12 years at the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development in Atlanta, retiring in 1990 after more than a decade of loyal service.

This resolution recognizes and commends the Latin American Association on its the mission to further the integration of Latino immigrants into the American society as workers, family members, students, and leaders.

This resolution declares the month of April, 2015 as Genocide Prevention and Awareness Month at the Capitol and invites the Georgia Coalition to Prevent Genocide to be recognized by the House of Representatives. It also recognizes the Eternal-Life Hemshech of Holocaust Survivors, the Georgia Commission on the Holocaust, the Jewish Community Relations Council of Atlanta, the National Center for Civil and Human Rights, the American Jewish Committee Atlanta Regional Office, and ACCESS Atlanta in their efforts to enhance the security and dignity of minority populations across the globe.

This resolution commends Jong Ho Lee's contributions in leadership and personal commitments to the welfare of all citizens. Jong Ho Lee, an immigrant from South Korea, was appointed the first Georgia president of the United States Taekwondo Union and later founded Taekwondo Aerobics.

This resolution honors the members of the St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee, Chairman Kevin Halligan and the Grand Marshal of the 2015 St. Patrick's Day Parade, Hugh Coleman on the upcoming 2015 St. Patrick's Day Parade in Savannah, Georgia, and invites them to be recognized by the House of Representatives. Savannah has proud Irish roots and its St. Patrick's Day celebration began in 1824 by the Hibernian Society of Savannah, which was formed to aid the early Irish immigrants to Georgia.

This resolution congratulates the Clarkston High School cross country team for their victorious performance in the 2014 Cross Country State Championship. The team reflects the community around them and is comprised of mostly refugees from Ethiopia, Kurdistan, Somalia, Democratic Republic of Congo, Eritrea and North Sudan.

This resolution recognizes February 7, 2012, as Catholic Day at the Georgia state capitol and commends the members of the Catholic faith for reaching out to all people in Georgia whether newcomers or long established, including refugees, immigrants, and those seeking asylum from oppression.

This resolution commends Jeffrey Tapia for her life of dedicated service. Under her supervision and direction, the Latin American Association (LAA) has been able to serve more than 50,000 people annually, helping Latinos achieve self-sufficiency, set down roots, and build a prosperous community. She has worked diligently to ensure that all of Georgia's children had access to public education, regardless of their immigration status.

This resolution honors the life and memory of Fred Toyosaburo Korematsu, son of Japanese immigrants who following the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, fought against forceable removal from the western coast based on his assertion of American loyalty despite his Japanese ancestry. Korematsu remained a tireless advocate for civil liberties and justice throughout his life and is a role model for all Americans who love the United States and the promises contained in the Constitution.

This resolution honors the life and memory of Jacob Groen. Jacob Groen was born in Antwerp, Belgium, in 1925, and was among the survivors of the Nazi death camps during World War II. He later immigrated to Georgia and made a significant impact on the Georgia community.

This resolution recognizes January 13, 2016, as Korean American Day at the State Capitol, and the large amount of Korean Immigrants who have immigrated into the United States and now live and contribute to the state of Georgia.
This resolution commends the Governor's Commission on Brookhaven, including Ben Vinson, the commission's chairman, who also serves as Chairman of the Georgia Immigration Enforcement Review Board.

This law authorizes the issuance of a temporary driving permit to noncitizen applicants whose State driver's license has expired, or will expire, who has filed a request for an extension to remain lawfully within the United States.

This law amends the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to security and immigration compliance. All public employers and contractors at every tier and level must use the federal work authorization program on all projects, jobs, and work resulting from any bid or contract. Further, every public employer and contractor working for a public employer must take all possible steps to ensure that a legal and eligible workforce is utilized in accordance with federal immigration and employment.

This law prohibits the transfer of student personally identifiable data to any federal, state, or local agency or nongovernmental organization, except for specified exceptions, including when the federal government requires the transfer of student data for a student classified as a 'migrant' for related federal program purposes.

This resolution recognizes and commends the members of the St. Patrick's day parade committee on the upcoming celebration of the 2012 St. Patrick's Day parade, an occasion that was begun by Hibernian Society of Savannah formed to aid the early Irish immigrants to Georgia.

This resolution recognizes and honors the St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee Chairman Michael A. Foran on the upcoming celebration of the 2012 St. Patrick's Day parade, an occasion that was begun by Hibernian Society of Savannah formed to aid the early Irish immigrants to Georgia.

This resolution recognizes and honors the St. Patrick's Day Parade Grand Marshal Timothy Tim Ansley on the upcoming celebration of the 2012 St. Patrick's Day parade, an occasion that was begun by Hibernian Society of Savannah formed to aid the early Irish immigrants to Georgia.
This resolution recognizes and commends Mr. James Foon Lee, a Chinese immigrant, on the occasion of his 90th birthday and wishes him many more years of happiness.

This resolution commends the 2016 St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee and recognizes the celebration's start by the Hibernian Society of Savannah, which was formed to aid early Irish immigrants in Georgia.
This resolution commends Good Samaritan Health Center of Gwinnett County, whose services are offered to all individuals regardless of immigration status.

This resolution recognizes February 12, 2013, as Interfaith Children's Movement Day at the state capitol. Interfaith Children's Movement is an interfaith advocacy movement dedicated to improving the well- being of children in Georgia, including children of immigrant families.

This resolution recognizes the month of April, 2015, as Genocide Prevention and Awareness Month at the Capitol and commends the Georgia Coalition to Prevent Genocide, Eternal-Life Hemshech of Holocaust Survivors, the Georgia Commission on the Holocaust, The Jewish Community Relations Council of Atlanta, The National Center for Civil and Human Rights, The American Jewish Committee Atlanta Regional Office, and ACCESS Atlanta in their efforts to enhance the security and dignity of minority populations across the globe.

This resolution, which honors members of the St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee, acknowledges the many Irish organizations have contributed to the longevity and success of this celebration, among the largest Irish celebrations in the country.

This resolution recognizes and honors the members of the St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee, Chairman Kevin Halligan and the Grand Marshal of the 2015 St. Patrick's Day Parade, Hugh Coleman on the upcoming occasion of the 2015 St. Patrick's Day Parade in Savannah, Georgia. Savannah has proud Irish roots and its St. Patrick's Day celebration began in 1824 by the Hibernian Society of Savannah, which was formed to aid the early Irish immigrants to Georgia.
This resolution urges the United States Congress to develop and implement a practical plan to secure the country's international borders and to appropriate adequate funds for that purpose.

This resolution honors January 13, 2016, as Korean American Day, recognizes pioneering Korean immigrants, and adds that the Korean American population in Georgia has increased by 95% in the last decade.
This resolution urges Congress to allow states to administer their own H-2A guest worker programs through the monitoring of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

This resolution recognizes February 7th 2012 as Catholic day at the Georgia state capitol and commends the members of the Catholic faith for reaching out to all people in Georgia whether newcomers or long established, including refugees, immigrants, and those seeking asylum from oppression.

This resolution recognizes February 9 as Community Health Centers Day. Community health centers provide high quality primary and preventive health care to 400,000 people in the State of Georgia, including Medicaid recipients, the uninsured, the working poor and immigrants.
This resolution recognizes February 4, 2016 as Catholic Day, and the efforts of the Archdiocese of Atlanta and the Diocese of Savannah in helping immigrants, refugees, and asylees.
This resolution congratulates Mr. David Kayango, an immigrant to the U.S., upon his appointment as the new CEO of the Center for Civil and Human Rights.

This resolution urges Congress to grow the United States economy by increasing the number of visas designed to permit Korean citizens possessing skills in a specialty occupation to work in the United States.
This resolution congratulates Mr. David Kayango, an immigrant to the U.S., upon his appointment as the new CEO of the Center for Civil and Human Rights.

This law authorizes the issuance of driver's licenses to residents of Hawaii who cannot provide proof of authorized presence in the U.S. Applicants must provide satisfactory proof of identity and Hawaii residency.

This law amends the duties of the workforce council to comply with the federal Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act and removes a reference to certain populations facing barriers in the workforce, including immigrants.

Effective July 1, 2012, this law moves the Office of Language Access from the Department of Labor and Industrial Relations to the Department of Health, in order to better serve limited English proficient individuals in accessing government services and programs. It also continues an advisory council, which includes a bilingual worker employed by a state-funded immigrant service agency or program.

This law eliminates the advisory council for community services which formerly assisted the executive director in formulating goals for programs and services benefitting the disadvantaged, refugees, and immigrants.

This law establishes a statewide language access resource center to assist individuals with limited English language proficiency in identifying qualified language interpreters and translators and to obtain information about the state resources that are available to them.
This resolution urges the President of the United States and Congress to support and pass the Filipino Veterans Family Reunification Act of 2013.
This resolution urges Congress and the U.S. Department of the Interior to restore federal healthcare funding for residents present under the compacts of free association.
This resolution requests the Governor to recognize local Koreans by placing commemorative plaques at the former sites of the Korean Christian Institute, to be funded by the Korean community.

This resolution requests access to justice commission to assemble various state and community entities to determine which agency or organization should administer funding for civil legal services to the low- and moderate-income. Civil legal services provides better access to the justice system to the indigent who are immigrants, homeless, at risk of homelessness, families in crisis, consumers who have been taken advantage of, and those who speak English as a second language.
This resolution congratulates the Hawaii Korean Chamber of Commerce on the occasion of its 75th Anniversary, having been established in 1940 by 15 Korean immigrants.

This resolution requests the auditor to conduct a review on the effect of the transfer from Medicaid to plans on the Hawaii Health Connector for non-eligible Medicaid Compact of Free Association Residents (COFA), an agreement to the Federated States of Micronesia, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Republic of Palau, to provide economic assistance to the populations of these nations by allowing them to enter, reside and work in the United States and to participate in certain federal programs such as Medicaid in exchange for the militarization and environmental degredation of their island homes.

This resolution urges the President and Congress to support and pass the Filipino Veterans Family Reunification Act of 2013, which would exempt the children of certain Filipino World War II veterans from the numerical limitations on immigration visas in order to facilitate reunification of Filipino veterans with their families.

This resolution urges the United States Department of Homeland Security to examine and re- evaluate its policies regarding refugee and asylee protections, including the principle of non-refoulement, to ensure that refugee and asylum seekers are guaranteed their universal human rights.

This resolution congratulates the Maryknoll Sisters for 100 years of dedicated service and honors their legacy and work to help those in need including children, abused women, immigrants, and the elderly.

This resolution recognizes and commends the Moiliili Japanese Cemetery Beautification Project for conducting historical research of and improving the Moiliili Japanese Cemetery, and preserving Japanese immigrant history.

This resolution acknowledges the important role that China and its people have played in Hawaii's economy and culture and the urges the U.S. Department of State, the Department of Homeland Security, and the U.S. Attorney General to include the People's Republic of China in the Visa Waiver Program, which would ease restrictions on business and tourist travelers from China.

This resolution supports the Visa Improvements to Stimulate International Tourism to the United States of America Act which would establish a five year multiple entry visa for Chinese visitors, and make other amendments in the visa process to increase tourism.

This resolution commemorates the thirtieth anniversary of Hawaii's sister-state relationship with the Guangdong Providence. Guangdong was Hawaii's first Chinese sister state because many early immigrants from China came to Hawaii from Guangdong, and over seventy-five per cent of people living in Hawaii can trace their ancestral roots back to the Guangdong province.

This resolution recognizes the 2012 Honpa Hongwanji mission of Hawaii's living treasures such as Barbara Fusako Kawakami who has dedicated her life to preserving Japanese immigrant culture and traditions.
This resolution urges the federal government to include Hong Kong in the U.S. Visa Waiver Program and ease visa restrictions and the visa application and approval process for business and tourism.

This resolution encourages the expansion of international ties and requests the Department of Education to support a student exchange program for students in Hawaiian public schools and students in the Republic of the Philippines where the state has State-Province relationships.

This resolution urges the United States Congress to include resident citizens of the Freely Associated States as qualified aliens under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act.

This resolution urges the Congress of the United States to propose and support the inclusion of the Philippines in the VISIT USA Act to boost Hawaii's tourism industry and strengthen the state's ties with the Philippines.

This law repeals the Senator Hiram L. Fong scholarship program, endowment trust, which provided financial support to qualifying students enrolled at any campus of the university with demonstrated interest and knowledge of the history of immigration to Hawaii.
Hawaii's immigrant health initiative program special fund is abolished.

This law provides support for the preservation of the Alien Internment Camp in Honolulu where over 1,000 Japanese-Americans, many innocent, were detained during World War II. The law also provides for an educational resource center at the site.

The law amends police department inquiries on firearm applicants to include use of the International Justice and Public Safety Network, which includes the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the National Crime Information Center, and the National Instant Criminal Background Check System.

This law declares that a start-up charter school shall be open to any student residing in the State who is entitled to attend a department school and that charter schools may give an enrollment preference through a weighted lottery to educationally disadvantaged students, which includes migrant students and limited English proficient students.

This resolution urges the United States Congress to allow citizens of the Freely Associated States who lawfully reside in the United States as qualified aliens access to federal benefits, including Medicaid, under the Personal Responsibility And Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996.

This resolution urges Hawaii's Congressional Delegation to seek and obtain additional federal aid to the state of Hawaii for the provision of educational services to migrants from the compact of free association Nations.
This resolution urges USCIS to immediately resume biometric intake and interviews to the counties of Hawaii, Maui, and Kauai.

This resolution commemorates the thirtieth anniversary of Hawaii's sister-state relationship with the Guangdong Providence. Guangdong was Hawaii's first Chinese sister state because many early immigrants from China came to Hawaii from Guangdong, and over seventy-five per cent of people living in Hawaii can trace their ancestral roots back to the Guangdong province.
This resolution urges Congress and the President to support the passage of legislation to expedite family reunification for certain Filipino Veterans of World War II.

This resolution urges the U.S. Congress to include resident citizens of the Freely Associated States who lawfully reside in the United States as qualified aliens under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 in recognizing their unique historic and ongoing contributions to the United States of America.

This resolution requests that the Department of Human Services consider amending the federal section 1115 waiver to raise the Medicaid income eligibility ceiling in the Basic Health Program under the federal Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The program currently allows eligibility for lawfully present non-immigrants and Compact of Free Association migrants.

This resolution urges state departments to work with the Hawaii State Commission on the Status of Women to develop gender analysis guidelines, including the analysis of immigration as linked to gender.
This law further defines human trafficking as knowingly purchasing or attempting to purchase sexual services from a victim or person engaged in human trafficking.

This appropriations law allocates funds to the economic development authority for the Iowa commission on volunteer services to be used for RefugeeRISE AmeriCorps program member recruitment and training to improve the economic well-being and health of economically disadvantaged refugees in local communities across Iowa.

This law relates to the state child labor law. It removes language requiring schools to certify that employed child laborers, between the ages of 10 and 16, are regularly attending school and the potential employment will not interfere with the student's progress in school. The child's employment can be with or without compensation, in street occupations or in migratory labor.
This law authorizes the economic development authority to charge fees for the usage of the authority's federal EB-5 immigrant investor regional center.

This budget allocates $210,000 for fiscal year 2015-16, and $105,000 for fiscal year 2016-17 for distribution to community college adult education and literacy programs, for the purpose of administering a pilot project providing Iowans with international resources and new Iowans access to economic and leadership development, making Iowa a more inclusive and welcoming place to live, work, and raise a family. The pilot project shall provide supplemental support services for international refugees to improve learning, English literacy, life skills, cultural competencies, and integration into their communities.

This law prohibits a public notary from acting as an immigration consultant or an expert on immigration matters. It further prohibits them from representing a person in a judicial or administrative proceeding relating to immigration to the United States, U.S. citizenship, or related matters.
This law appropriates $210,000 to a pilot project that shall provide supplemental support services for international refugees to improve learning, literacy, cultural competencies, and assimilation.

This law provides an exemption from massage therapy licensing laws for the practice of massage therapy by persons licensed, registered or certified in another state, a territory, the District of Columbia or a foreign country when practicing on clients participating in organized athletic events or affiliated with or employed by established athletic teams, athletic organizations or performing arts companies temporarily practicing, competing or performing in the state for no more than 60 days in a calendar year.
This resolution commemorates the 130th Anniversary of the Statue of Liberty, which has welcomed more than twelve million immigrants to American shores.

Applicants for a class A, B or C driver's licenses or commercial learner's permits must provide proof of U.S. citizenship or lawful permanent residency upon application for issuance, transfer, upgrade or renewal, unless the applicant's driving record already contains documentation confirming citizenship or lawful permanent residency. Applicants for a nondomiciled class A, B or C driver's license or commercial learner's permit domiciled in a foreign country must provide an unexpired employment authorization document issued by the Department of Homeland Security or an unexpired foreign passport accompanied by an approved I-94 form documenting the applicant's most recent admittance into the U.S.

This law requires high school students to successfully complete a civics test, which includes questions used by U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, to demonstrate a knowledge and understanding of the fundamentals of U.S. history and the principles and form of U.S. government.

The law amends higher education residency requirements. The definition of nonresident student for tuition purposes includes a student attending an Idaho public institution of higher education with financial assistance provided by another country or governmental unit, and a student who is not a United States citizen, unless lawfully present in the United States.

This law, known as the Student Data Accessibility, Transparency and Accountability Act of 2014, provides for confidentiality of student information. It states that any data deemed confidential shall not be released to any federal, state or local agency or other organization or entity outside of the state of Idaho. Exceptions include students classified as 'migrants' for reporting purposes as required by the federal government.
The law changes references to the Basic Pilot Program to the E-Verify Program in order to conform to changes made by federal Public Law 111-83.

This law relates to individuals with education outside of the United States and amends provisions of the Dental Practice Act requiring applicants for a dental license who did not graduate from a dental school in the United States or Canada to complete a certain number of years of general dental clinical training in the United States or Canada prior to licensure, removes provisions allowing the applicant to substitute other forms of training and requiring the applicant to have received specified certification from a dean of an approved college or school.
This law, which appropriates funds for FY 14, designates funds for Grants and Administrative Expenses associated with Immigrant Integration Services and for other immigrant services.
This law limits fees charged by notary publics for immigration forms.
This law requires monthly reports on enrollment in medical assistance programs, including demographic and language preference data.

This law provides that adoption of a child who is a resident of a foreign country by a resident of the United States shall comply with the Intercountry Adoption Act of 2000 and the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Department of Children and Family Services shall maintain the office of Intercountry Adoption Coordinator in order to maintain and protect the rights of prospective adoptive parents and children.

This law establishes the Office of New Americans to more effectively assist immigrants in overcoming barriers to success and shall facilitate host communities' ability to capitalize on the assets of their immigrant populations. The Office of New Americans shall identify strategic partnerships with State agencies to implement best practices, policies, and procedures and make recommendations for statewide policy and administrative changes.

This law amends the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District Act to permit a person who is legally authorized to work in the United States to be employed under contracts for work to be done with the District.

This law allows an exception for applicants for an architecture license who have graduated from an architectural program outside the United States, and whose first language is not English, to not be required to submit certification of passage of the TOEFL or a test of spoken English, if the applicant earned an advanced degree from an accredited educational institution in the United States or its territories.
This law amends Criminal Code to penalize trafficking in persons and deletes all previous references to forced labor or services.
This law appropriates $6,673,600 towards grants and administrative Expenses associated with Immigrant Integration Services and for other Immigrant Services pursuant to 305 ILCS 5/12-4.34.

No person shall be denied the right to register to vote or to cast a ballot in an election based on race, color, ethnicity, status as a member of a language minority, national origin, religion, sex, sexual orientation, or income.

This resolution directs the Bilingual Advisory Task Force to see professional certification standards for foreign language educational interpreters would be feasible and would help immigrant parents be more involved in their children's' education.

This resolution, which acknowledges the hardships and barriers to those with limited English proficiency, establishes a task force to identify the effectiveness of current language programs, to come up with new program ideas, and to recognize best practices.

This resolution urges President Barack Obama to nominate a Supreme Court Justice and urges his confirmation by the U.S. Senate, as the Supreme Court will hear a significant case (among others) impacting immigration this year.

Congratulates Kathy Bovid on her remarkable 29 year career in healthcare, including most recently as Associate Director of State Government Affairs at Bristol-Myers Squib. She was born and raised in Michigan, while her father was born in Illinois, her Lithuanian and Swedish immigrant grandparents all lived and worked in Chicago in their early adult years.
This resolution mourns the death of Justice Antonin Gregory Scalia, the only son of an Italian immigrant from Sicily.

Recognizes the Polish American Police Association as a proactive organization interested in fostering the fraternal, ethnic, cultural, educational, civic, charitable, political, and professional interests of its members and the Polish-Slavic communities, the association provides financial and manpower support for various social service and professional organizations that provide services to the immigrant and Polish- American community.
This resolution mourns the death of Peter Krystian Domaradzk, an esteemed Polish American journalist, essayist, and historian who immigrated with his family to America in 1985.

Recognizes Douglas Whitley who has held leadership positions with numerous business and civic organizations, he co-founded and co-chairs the Transportation for Illinois Coalition and currently serves on the Board of Directors for the Illinois Technology Partnership and on the Steering Committee for the Illinois Business Immigration Coalition.
This resolution congratulates Tema Posalska Bauer on her 100th birthday. Tema is one of less than 300,000 Polish Jews to survive the Holocaust, and immigrated with her husband to Chicago in 1949.

This resolution recognizes the plight of non-citizen veterans and urges the United States Congress and the President of the United States to provide these veterans and their families the honors and benefits that they have earned.
This resolution congratulate Kazimiera Bober on the occasion of her 40th anniversary of her immigration to the United States and the 36th anniversary of starting her business.

This resolution brings the cases of the legal permanent resident veterans who were deported to the attention of the members of Congress and to the President of the United States in a determined effort to win the return of these veterans to their families, children, and communities in the United States.

This resolution recognize Abdheja Abby Mohansundr on her Bharathanatyam dancing skills and her instruction and promotion of the dance to future generations. She is an immigrant from India and naturalized U.S. citizen.
This resolution thanks Sam Ma for his work for Chicago's Chinatown community and for the State of Illinois and his focus on immigration issues.
This resolution congratulates the Second Baptist Church in Elgin on its 150th anniversary, established by a group of freed slaves and refugees in 1862.

This resolution congratulates Sister Kathleen Ryan on winning the Aurora Deanery Council of Catholic Women Award and recognizes her as the founder of the Dominican Literacy Center in Aurora that gives immigrant women free tutoring in reading, writing, and speaking English, and for helping prepare immigrant women and men to take the United States citizenship exam.
This resolution recognizes the 125th anniversary of the St. Joseph Catholic Church in Joliet, which was founded by Slovenian immigrants.

This resolution congratulates Alfredo Talip on the occasion of his 90th birthday on February 25, 2015. Talip was born on February 25, 1925 in San Fernando, Tamaulipas, Mexico and in his early adult life he labored as a seasonal migrant farm worker traveling back and forth from Mexico to southern Texas to find work until he immigrated to Illinois in 1951. In 1959, Alfredo Talip was one of the founding members of the Aurora Latin American Club, the first social and cultural club for Mexicans and Tejanos in Aurora.
Illinois recognizes June 2015 as Immigration Heritage Month.

This resolution designates a section of Interstate 57 that encompasses an area where the first non- Native Americans in Illinois settled as the French-Canadian Heritage Corridor. The majority of settlers, and the first significant ethnic groups to make contributions to the area, were French-Canadian pioneers who immigrated in large numbers to what is now Kankakee and Iroquois Counties from the late 1820s to 1850s.
This resolution recognizes Ricardo Ramirez, the son of Mexican immigrants, for his athletic and academic achievements.
This resolution urges the President and the U.S. Congress to enact comprehensive immigration reform.

The members of the Illinois House of Representatives are saddened to learn of the death of Charles J. Charlie Myler of Aurora, who passed away on April 6, 2015. After receiving his law degree, Charles Myler was drafted into the United States Army, he was chosen to be a member of the Counter Intelligence Corps and was eventually sent to Nuremberg, Germany during the 1956 Hungarian Revolution and spent two years working in refugee camps, aiding refugees from behind the Iron Curtain.
This law congratulates Margaret Steinway, the daughter of Irish immigrants, on her 90th birthday.

This resolution, celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Bahamas Independence, acknowledges the recent enhancement of bilateral cooperation and the deepening of social and trade ties by the visit to Illinois by the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Immigration of the Commonwealth.
This resolution congratulates Family Focus of Aurora, which partners with the Illinois Coalition for Immigrant and Refugee Rights, on its 30th anniversary.

This resolution designates October 13, 2013 as B'nai B'rith Day in the State of Illinois in honor of the 170th anniversary of B'nai B'rith International, which seeks to improve the lives of new German Jewish immigrants to America.
This resolution honors the 42nd anniversary of La Voz Latina, an organization which provides assistance to Hispanic families new to the Rockford community.
This resolution honors Dr. Gerhard Malcharek, immigrant from Czechoslovakia (now the Czech Republic), for his service to his country and for living his dreams through the practice of dentistry.

This resolution to congratulates the members of Hadassah on the occasion of the organization's 100th anniversary on February 24, 2012 and commends their contribution to the education and nurturing of young immigrants and their advocacy positions on immigration and voting rights.

Expresses solidarity with the North Korean refugees in their quest for relief from hunger and persecution, articulates support for development of a Human Rights and Democracy program and calls upon the United States government to take a leadership role in forming an international framework for resettlement of North Korean refugees both here and abroad.
Congratulates the congregation of Baileyville Baptist Church on the occasion of the church's 150th anniversary. Founded by German immigrants.
Mourns the death of Anthony Yaw Sarfo Kwateng of Munster, Indiana. Immigrant and Founder of Ghana USA Chamber of Commerce.
This resolution congratulates Beulah E. Posten of Chicago, an immigrant from Panama, on her centennial birthday.

The members of the Illinois House of Representatives are saddened by the death of our friend and colleague, former State Representative Rosemary Mulligan of Des Plaines, who passed away on December 30, 2014. Representative Mulligan was known for her extensive work in social issues, including immigration. This resolution honors Lin-Manuel Miranda, the son of Puerto Rican immigrants, for his contributions to art and civics education through his composition of the musical Hamilton.

This resolution designates February 18, 2012 as Utah's congressional Gold Medal Day for the Utah Nisei veterans of the 100th Infantry Battalion serving despite the Executive Order 9066 that forcibly removed and incarcerated 120,000 people of Japanese ancestry and the Nisei Military Intelligence Service (MIS), consisting of over 3,000 Japanese Americans, who served in all campaigns in the Pacific Theater of War.
This law establishes new educational scholarships and requires applicants to certify they are U.S. citizens or noncitizens eligible for federal aid.

This law amends language to allow graduates with a master's degree in a social work program accredited by the Canadian Association of Schools of Social Work to qualify for licensure or certification as a clinical social worker, certified social worker, and social service worker, and those holding a bachelor's degree in a social work program accredited by the Canadian Association of Schools of Social Work to qualify as a social worker intern.

This law authorizes the division to issue a license as an occupational therapist or as an occupational therapy assistant to an applicant who meets the requirements of receiving a license, and has been licensed in a state, district, or U.S. territory, or in a foreign country, where the education, experience, or examination requirements are not substantially equal to the requirements of this state, if the applicant passes an applicable examination.

The Immigration Consultants Registration Act defines an immigration consultant as a person who provides nonlegal assistance or advice on an immigration matter and it establishes certain requirements, such as registration, background check and posting of a bond.

As part of the fingerprint and photograph submission required for driving privilege card applicants and cardholders, notification of any existing criminal history record or existing or new warrant information and any new criminal history record information entered in local, state, or federal databases shall be made to the federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agency of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.

This law extends the program start date under the Utah Immigration Accountability and Enforcement Act, and dates for the Utah Pilot Sponsored Resident Immigrant Program Act under which a resident immigrant may reside, work, and study in Utah. The program may not permit a resident immigrant to travel outside of the state except under certain circumstances.

This law extends the trigger date for implementation of the Utah guest worker program from July 2013 to July 2015. The law also extends the Utah pilot resident immigrant program, delaying the start date from July 2013 to July 2015, and ending in June 2020 instead of 2018.
This law provides an exemption to verification of lawful presence for privately funded scholarships administered by colleges or universities, for graduates of Utah high schools.
This law repeals the Utah Commission on Immigration and Migration Act.
This supplemental appropriations law provides $150,000 to Refugee Assistance for the year ending June 30, 2012.

The State legislature intends that the Department of Health remove the optional 5 year waiting period for legal immigrant children who currently qualify for 100% federal funding in the Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance program.

This law amends the American Civics Education Initiative, requiring all high school graduates to pass a civics test, to define basic civics test as a test that includes 50 of the 100 questions on the civics test form used by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services to determine that an individual applying for U.S. citizenship meets the basic citizenship skills specified.
This appropriations law includes $5,942,600 for Refugee Assistance for the year ending June 30, 2013.
This social services law includes $10,170,000 for services for refugees.
This law authorizes fees for occupational and professional licensing, including a $200 Immigration Consultant initial registration fee, and $200 for license renewal.

This law creates an exemption to licensure requirements for the practice of dentistry for certain faculty of accredited dental schools if the individual meets certain qualifications, including holding a license to practice dentistry in another jurisdiction, being permitted to the work in the United States under federal immigration law, and complying with other restrictions as outlined.

This law repeals section 63G-13-203 of the Utah Code, Collaboration on integration of immigrants. The collaboration urged the Utah Commission on Immigration and Migration to work with federal, state, and local governments to facilitate integration of immigrants in the state.

This resolution gives the Legislative Management Committee items of study which includes the removal of the five-year waiting period to provide Medicaid coverage and health insurance coverage to a legal immigrant child.
This law mandates training and information on human trafficking, especially trafficking of children, and strategies to prevent trafficking shall be provided to local school staff.
This law requires adult entertainment businesses to post notice of the National Human Trafficking Resource Center Hotline to alert potential trafficking victims of the availability of assistance.
This law appropriates $1,304,048 per year for 2 years for inmate medical costs from the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program.
This law, relating to concealed handgun permits, adds the U.S. Customs and Border Protection to the list of agencies whose retirees receive fee exemptions.

A person domiciled in a foreign jurisdiction and meeting all the requirements may apply for a nondomiciled commercial learner's permit or nondomiciled commercial driver's license. They must provide an unexpired employment authorization document issued by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services or an unexpired foreign passport accompanied by an approved Form I-94 documenting the applicant's most recent admittance into the United States. Those who hold one of these certifications must notify the Department if any adverse action is taken by any jurisdiction or governmental agency, foreign or domestic, against their driving privileges.
This law requires a commissioned notary to be a legal resident of the United States.

This law requires the institution to notify the Attorney General if a student fails to enroll, withdraws, or violates his or her visa in some way. The Attorney General will notify the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services and other appropriate agencies. Students with an immigration visa or classified as a political refugee may establish domicile. However, absent congressional intent to the contrary, any individual holding a student visa or another temporary visa does not have the capacity to intend to remain in the Commonwealth indefinitely and is therefore ineligible to establish domicile and receive in-state tuition charges.
This appropriations law includes funds for the Criminal Alien Assistance Program for inmate medical costs and for English language learners.

This law prohibits a notary public from offering or providing legal advice to any person in immigration matters or representing any person in immigration proceedings unless such notary public is an attorney or a federally accredited representative, requires notaries to include in any non-English advertising a statement that the notary is not licensed to practice law and has no authority to give advice on immigration or other legal matters.
This budget law funds community and migrant health centers and the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program.
This appropriations law funds SNAP outreach to eligible immigrants and the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program.
This law exempts retired Immigration and Customs officers, among other retired public servants, from the fee of applying for a concealed handgun license/permit.

This law makes consistent the type of identification and other documentation that a purchaser of a firearm must present to a licensed dealer by removing the additional requirement for the purchase of an assault weapon that a person who purchases such a weapon must present proof of citizenship. It does not alter the provisions prohibiting the sale of assault firearms to noncitizens who have not been lawfully admitted for permanent residence.

This resolution designates April 16, in 2016 and in each succeeding year, as Chagas Disease Awareness Day in Virginia, and recognizes the prevalence of Chagas Disease in Bolivian immigrants, and adds that the Latin American population is at high risk for Chagas Disease.

This resolution commends Belle View Elementary School for adapting to the increasing immigration to the Washington D.C. area by creating an English as a Second Language program to better meet the needs of students.

This resolution commends Just Neighbors, a community-based nonprofit organization in Northern Virginia, for developing practical responses to the legal challenges faced by immigrants to the United States.

The General Assembly notes with great sadness the loss of Bassam Khalil Abdallah of Centreville, a devoted husband and father who immigrated to this country from Lebanon when he was a young man and became a proud citizen of the United States

This resolution commends Dr. Emma Violand-Sanchez, a Bolivian immigrant, for her work in aiding immigrants, including founding the Dream Project.

This resolution commends Dr. Rita Chi-Ying Chung, the daughter of Chinese immigrants in New Zealand, who studied ways to work with Asian refugees and co-developed culturally sensitive models of psychotherapy.

This resolution commends the Family Counseling Center of Greater Washington for its service to the community on the occasion of its 40th anniversary and for helping Asian Americans and recent immigrants overcome linguistic and cultural challenges and become active, well-adjusted members of their communities.
This resolution commemorates Gracelia Joy R. Helring for her more than 70 years of diligent community service and leadership, including her service as an immigration lawyer for 30 years.

The General Assembly commends Business Development Assistance Group, Inc., for more than 20 years of service to the community and recognizes its work to provide new opportunities for immigrants and minorities and enhance the local, state, and national economies.

This resolution commend Robin Stern Hamby for three decades of service to the youths of Fairfax County and the Commonwealth. Under Robin Hamby's able leadership, the Immigrant Family Reunification Program offers training for school staff and service providers and workshops for parents and is developing parent-led support groups.

This resolution recognizes the African American members elected to the Virginia Constitutional Convention of 1867-1868 and members elected to the Virginia General Assembly including Goodman Brown who served on the House Immigration and the Retrenchment and Economy Committees.
This resolution commends the Historic Triangle Community Services Center, which partnered with numerous organizations in 2014, including L&L Immigration Law.
This resolution commemorates the 50th anniversary of the signing of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965.

This resolution celebrates the life of Ranjit Kumar Sen, an Indian immigrant who was an innovative and visionary businessman and a recipient of a Humanitarian Award from the Virginia Center for Inclusive Communities.

This resolution commends the Virginia Mentoring Partnership, which encourages organizations to reach out to a variety of youth, including those in single-parent households, born to teen parents, living in poverty, and from first-generation immigrant families.

This resolution celebrates the life of the Reverend Richard B. Martin and his work, including efforts made with Virginians Organized for Interfaith Community Engagement to promote affordable housing and career opportunities for immigrants.

This resolution celebrates the life of the respected oral surgeon, Rafael Fernando Madan, KHS, D.D.S, a Cuban native whose family escaped to the United States as political and religious refugees after the Cuban Revolution.
This resolution commends Harry Thomas Kolendrianos, the son of an immigrant, on his selection by the Kiwanis Club of Danville as its 2012 Citizenship Award recipient.
This resolution celebrates the life of Mohammad Taib, an immigrant from Pakistan.
This resolution mourns the death of Edna B. Ipson, who was a Jewish immigrant, Holocaust survivor, and who is recognized for her service to the Jewish community.
This resolution mourns the death of Fred Rabil, who was a second-generation Lebanese immigrant and respected restaurant owner in the Franklin community.

This resolution honors the life of Ukranian native Eugenia Genie Weisman Evans, a former music professor at Shenandoah University who fled to America in 1940 as a refugee. Having studied at the prestigious Prague Conservatory, Genie Evans has trained rising generations of musicians in the Leschetizky method.
This resolution commends the Korean American Foundation of the United States of America on the occasion of the 110th anniversary of Korean immigration to the United States.

This resolution commends the Korean Community Service Center of Greater Washington on the occasion of its 40th anniversary. The Center's mission is to improve the quality of life for the growing Asian American population in the metropolitan Washington, D.C., area and help new immigrants become active, well-adjusted members of their communities.

This law requires the State Board apply for participation in the Systematic Alien Verification for Entitlements (SAVE) system to verify that voters listed in the Virginia voter registration system are U.S. citizens.

This law amends voter identification requirements by adding valid United States passports to the list of valid forms of identification and eliminating those forms of identification that do not contain a photograph of the voter.
This law requires the dissemination of human trafficking awareness and training materials for local school staff, including strategies for the prevention of child trafficking.

This law states that the State Registrar of Vital Records will establish and register a new birth certificate for persons born in a foreign country once provided with proof of adoption, legitimation or determination of paternity.

This law amends the Code of Virginia to require the State Board of Elections to delete from its record of registered voters the names of voters who are known not to be U.S. citizens by reason of reports from the Department of Motor Vehicles, or from information received from the Systematic Alien Verification for Entitlements Program (SAVE Program). The State Board shall apply to participate in the SAVE Program operated by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security for the purposes of verifying that voters in the voter registration system are U.S. citizens.

This law amends the Code of Virginia to require the State Board of Elections to delete from its record of registered voters the names of voters who are known not to be U.S. citizens by reason of reports from the Department of Motor Vehicles, or from information received from the Systematic Alien Verification for Entitlements Program (SAVE Program). The State Board shall apply to participate in the SAVE Program operated by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security for the purposes of verifying that voters in the voter registration system are U.S. citizens.

This law prohibits notary publics from offering or providing legal advice on immigration matters representing anyone in immigration proceedings unless otherwise authorized as an attorney or a federally accredited representative. It prohibits notary publics from advertising the title of notario, notario public, or licenciado, or a term in a language other than English that indicates that the notary is authorized to provide legal advice or practice law. Violations will be met with civil penalties not exceeding $500 for a first violation and $1,000 for a second or subsequent violation. The Secretary may revoke the commission of any notary who fails to exercise the powers or perform the duties of a notary public in accordance with this title.

This law allows for the payment of medical assistance for eligible pregnant women during the first five years of lawful residence in the United States, pursuant to Section 214 of the Children's Health Insurance Program Reauthorization Act of 2009.
This law, relating to concealed handgun permits, adds the U.S. Customs and Border Protection to the list of agencies whose retirees receive fee exemptions.

This resolution recognizes Goodman Brown who served on the House Immigration and the Retrenchment Committees and other African American members elected to the Virginia General Assembly during Reconstruction as part of the commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation.

This resolution commends Virginia Organizing, a nonprofit grassroots organization with chapters throughout the Commonwealth, for 20 years of empowering and encouraging individuals to work together to strengthen their communities. Virginia Organizing does work pertaining to a number of social justice issues, including immigration, poverty, and anti-racism.
This resolution commends Earl Hamner, Jr., a descendent of Italian immigrant Anthony Giannini, for his lifelong contributions to literature.

This resolution commends Robert G. Templin for committing his life to improving the lives of Virginians through his efforts on workforce training, education, immigration policy, and economic development.
This resolution celebrates the life of Myron Parsek Erkiletian, son of Turkish migrants.

This resolution designated April 30 as South Vietnamese Recognition Day in Virginia to honor the bravery and sacrifices of South Vietnamese soldiers in their battle against communist forces during the Vietnam War. This resolution further acknowledges the talent and intellect of those South Vietnamese immigrants who fled from the tortures of concentration camps. Today, 82 percent of South Vietnamese in the U.S. are native-born or naturalized citizens.
This law creates an EB-5 special fund for the operation of the state of Vermont regional center for immigrant investment under the federal EB-5 program.

This law amends the Vermont EB5 Regional Center's oversight of the EB-5 program, a federal program designed to stimulate the economy though job creation and capitol investments by foreign investors. It states the legislative intent that the Regional Center function as a self-funded entity instead of relying in part on legislative appropriations. It authorizes administrative charges to fund the personnel and operating costs of the center. Legislative intent is that costs of EB-5 regulation should not be paid with State funds.

This resolution commemorates Women's History Month and the publication of the sixth edition of The Legal Rights of Women in Vermont which covers legal issues affecting all Vermonters including education, immigration and public assistance.
This resolution supports U.S. federal humanitarian assistance for Tibetan refugees.
This resolution supports Rutland City's welcoming of 100 Syrian refugees.

This law, which describes qualifications and requirements relating to commercial driver's licenses and permits, requires that any applicant domiciled in a foreign jurisdiction provide documentation of employment authorization and lawful status in the United States.
This law revokes a former exemption of snowmobile tags along the American/Canadian border.
This law allows those Vermont residents unable to establish lawful presence in the United States be eligible for a [motor vehicle] operator's privilege card or alternate identification card.

This law, which provides relief from abuse by another family or household member, authorizes the court to order that the defendant return personal documentation, including immigration documents, to the plaintiff seeking protection.

This Joint Resolution encourages public high schools to explore recruiting and enrolling international students on F-1 student visas in order to promote tuition-based income, and expose F-1 students and public school K-12 Vermont students to enriched cross-cultural learning experiences.
This appropriations law includes funding for low-income housing, including veterans, refugees and immigrants in the definition of underserved communities of concern.

This law requires the department to create and administer the agricultural labor skills and safety grant program to provide training opportunities open to all Washington agricultural workers, including seasonal migrant workers who intend to return to Washington state to work in the state's agriculture.

This appropriations law for fiscal year 2012 and 2013 funds naturalization services at $1,657,000 and refugee employment services at $2,366,000, of which $1,774,000 is provided solely for the department to pass through to statewide refugee assistance organizations for limited English proficiency pathway services. On December 1, 2011, and annually thereafter, the department must report to the legislature on all sources of funding available for both refugee and immigrant services and naturalization services during the current fiscal year and the amounts expended to date by service type and funding source. The report must also include the number of clients served and outcome data for the clients.

The Department of Transportation must evaluate the feasibility of utilizing the federal EB-5 immigrant investor program for financing the construction of a safety of life at sea (SOLAS) certificated vessel for the Anacortes-Sidney ferry route.
This law establishes a joint legislative task force on the use of deadly force in community policing, including members from the Northwest immigration rights project.
This resolution celebrates the centennial of the birth of Senator Henry M. Scoop Jackson of Washington state, son of Norwegian immigrants.

This resolution honors Representative Phyllis Gutierrez Kenney who cofounded the Washington State Migrant Child Care Centers and has been a tireless champion for minorities in the State of Washington.
This law provides appropriations for employment services for refugees and immigrants.

The department shall issue an initial limited license without an examination to any applicant who, as determined by the secretary: holds a valid license in a Canadian province that allows a substantively equivalent scope of practice, is currently engaged in active practice in a Canadian province, files with the secretary documentation certifying that the applicant has graduated from an accredited dental hygiene school, has successfully completed the dental hygiene national board examination, and is licensed to practice in a Canadian province. Additionally, a person licensed in a Canadian province who can demonstrate substantively equivalent licensing standards in the administration of local anesthetic may receive a temporary endorsement to administer local anesthesia, and a person licensed in a Canadian province who can demonstrate substantively equivalent licensing standards in restorative procedures may receive a temporary endorsement for restorative procedures.

This amendment adds language to current law to declare that domestic violence assistance and advocacy may include accompaniment and advocacy through immigration systems. It also adds language stating that department shall consider the distribution of community-based domestic violence programs and emergency shelter programs based on geographic area, population density, and specific population needs, including the needs in rural and urban areas, the availability and existence of domestic violence outreach and prevention activities, and the need for culturally and linguistically appropriate services.

This law specifies that all student data-related reports required of the superintendent of public instruction regarding student suspensions and expulsions be subject to cross-tabulation by categories including whether the student is from a migrant population.

The department of Transportation must evaluate the feasibility of utilizing the federal EB-5 immigrant investor program for financing the construction of a safety of life at sea (SOLAS) certificated vessel for the Anacortes-Sidney ferry route. The department must establish a group that includes, but is not limited to, the department of commerce and entities or individuals experienced with vessel engineering and EB-5 financing for assistance in evaluating the applicability of the EB-5 immigrant investor program. The department must deliver a report containing the results of the evaluation to the transportation committees of the legislature and the office of financial management by December 1, 2015.
This law appropriates $50,000 of the general fund, for both fiscal years 2014 and 2015, solely for the immigration consequences advisement program at the Washington defenders association.

This law appropriates $2,366,000 from the 2016 general fund of the Department of Social and Health Services - Economic Services Program solely for employment services for refugees and immigrants, of which $1,774,000 is provided for the department to pass through to statewide refugee and immigrant assistance organizations for limited English proficiency pathway services. Additionally, on December 1, 2015 and every year after, the department must submit a report to the legislature, including the sources of all funding for refugee and immigrant services, the amounts of money spent on related services, and the number of clients served and their outcomes.

This law relates to paraeducator development and states that the professional educator standards board shall convene a work group to design employment standards for paraeducators, and that the work group must include representatives from, among other groups, community-based organizations representing immigrant and refugee communities. It appropriates funds for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2015 for the work group from the general fund to the professional educator standards board.

This law recognizes January 11 as human trafficking awareness day. In 2002, Washington was the first state in the United States to create a state antitrafficking of persons task force, safety measures for noncitizen nonresident persons recruited by international matchmaking organizations, and a definition of human trafficking crimes at the state level.

This law, also known as the Real Hope Act, expands higher education opportunities like state need grants to individuals who have been granted deferred action for childhood arrival status, who have completed the full senior year of high school and obtained a high school diploma or an equivalent, who have lived in Washington state for at least 3 years immediately before receiving the diploma or its equivalent, and have continued to live in the state of Washington until admitted to an eligible institute of higher education. The law also appropriates funds for student financial aid payments under the state need grant program. (DREAM Act)

This resolution relates to human trafficking. The Washington State Senate supports increased education, stronger laws and law enforcement, and the promotion of justice to reduce the exploitation of all people, including women and children.

This resolution acknowledges the nation's founding by immigrants who escaped government- sanctioned persecution of their faith in their home countries and proclaims that diverse religious beliefs, traditions, and heritages are welcome in the state of Washington.

This resolution celebrates the City of Kent's 125th anniversary and recognizes the hundreds of early immigrants who were attracted to the Valley to farm fruits and vegetables. Kent is now home to a culturally fluent population that collectively speaks 137 different languages.
This resolution reaffirms Washington State's commitment to being a safe and secure home for refugees.
This resolution honors the memory of Justice Antonin Scalia, the son of an Italian immigrant.

This law appropriates funds for refugee assistance and provides funding authorization to aid in the development of the Norskedalen Nature and Heritage Center heritage site in Vernon County in order to preserve the historical and archaeological heritage of the many immigrant groups and American Indian tribes or bands who have contributed to Wisconsin's cultural, social, and economic life.
This resolution mourns the death of Jean Lucey, daughter of Greek immigrants and commends her public service to her community and the state of Wisconsin.

The Wisconsin legislature proclaims the weekend of May 16, 17, and 18, 2014, Syttende Mai Weekend in the state of Wisconsin, and declares that all citizens of this state are honorary Norwegians for that weekend and are urged to observe the Syttende Mai Weekend with appropriate celebrations.

This resolution proclaims the weekend of May 18, 19, and 20, 2012, Syttende Mai Weekend in Wisconsin, and urges all residents to observe the Syttende Mai Weekend in celebration of Norwegian immigrants and their countless contributions to the cultures of Wisconsin and other regions of the United States.
This resolution proclaims October 6, 2011, to be German-American Day in commemoration of German immigrants and their contribution to the American workforce and society.
Proclaims October as Italian-American Heritage Month

This resolution proclaims the week of January 29 through February 5 to be Catholic Schools Week celebrating Marquette University, founded in 1857 to educate Catholic immigrants and aid families and the community.
This appropriations law includes funding for refugee programs and addreses limited-English proficient students.
This resolution honors the memory of Joseph LaPorte, born to Sicilian immigrants, for his life and service to the people of Waukesha, Wisconsin.

This resolution mourns the death of Robert K. Zukowski, who among his many accomplishments brought a Wisconsin Historical Marker to Old St. Hedwig's Catholic Cemetery to honor the local Polish immigrants.
This resolution proclaims May 15-17, 2015, Syttende Mai Weekend. It recognizes Norwegian immigrants and their countless contributions to Wisconsin and the U.S.

This law, which relates to the licensure of insurance adjusters, adds a clause that a resident of Canada may be licensed as a nonresident adjuster if he/she holds a resident or home state adjuster license in another state.

This law authorizes the Higher Education Policy Commission (Medical Student Loan Program) with an amendment that specifies that in order to be eligible for this loan, an applicant must be a U.S. citizen, or legal immigrant actively pursuing U.S. citizenship.

This resolution requests that the CSX overpass bridge on Kanawha Terrace, West Virginia, be named the Norbert E. Eagloski Memorial Bridge after Norbert E. Eagloski, son of Polish immigrants, veteran of World War II.

This resolution concerns installing signs at the entrances of the Historic Dingess Tunnel to commemorate its 100 years of history. The Dingess Tunnel, constructed largely by immigrant workers that decided to stay in Mingo County upon its completion, allowed thousands of tons of coal to be mined, thus allowing the employment of thousands of hard-working coal miners.
This resolution proclaims the fiddle as the official musical instrument of the State of West Virginia. The fiddle came from immigrants from the British Isles.
This law amends current law to require new employees working on capitol grounds to have employment eligibility confirmed through E-Verify.

This resolution requests that a portion of U. S. Route 60 from Mile Post 31.50 to Mile Post 40.00 in Kanawha County be named the Lou Tabit Highway in honor of the creator and chairman of the Committee to Upgrade U.S. Route 60, also the son of immigrants from Lebanon.

This resolution requests the naming of a memorial bridge in Anmoore, Harrison County, heading south the U.S. Army PFC Nick A.Cavallaro Memorial Bridge and heading north the U.S. Army SSG Benjamin T.Portaro Memorial Bridge. Nick Cavallaro and Benjamin Portaro were Italian immigrants, cousins and citizens of Anmoore, West Virginia, and fought for the United States in World War II.

This resolution requests the Division of Highways to rename a bridge, locally known as Gary Bridge, the U.S. Army CPL Zane Joseph Gero and U.S. Marine Corps CPL John Anthony 'Tony' Gero Memorial Bridge. Gero was born January 26, 1911, in Thorpe, McDowell County, into a coal-mining family of immigrant ancestors. In a partly segregated community Gero was welcomed by all ethnic and racial groups. He spoke numerous languages and at times acted as an interpreter. He was mortally wounded in Vietnam.
This resolution requests that the Division of Highways rename a bridge the, U. S. Marine Corps SGT Mike Plasha Memorial Bridge. He was the son of immigrants and a decorated veteran.
This resolution honors Mineral County's 150th anniversary and recognizes its ethnic and cultural diversity due to immigrants settling in the area in the 19th century.

This resolution welcomes refugees and declares support for the resettlement of refugees in California, no matter their religion, race, nationality, sexual orientation, gender identity, or country of origin, and calls upon other local governments and communities to join them in supporting a stronger national effort to resettle the world's most vulnerable refugees. This resolution also calls on the federal government to resettle all 30,000 refugees that the U.S. has committed to resettle in fiscal year 2019 and to increase admissions to 75,000 for fiscal year 2020.
